isis.stitle: POWER STEERING GEAR: SHEPPARD M-SERIES - PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE - INPUT SHAFT SEAL REPLACEMENT

svcprocinfo.para: Current Production after July 1990 - the input bearing cap will not have a grease fitting (Figure 16).

figure.caption: Figure 16. Grease Fitting On Cap Cover

important.para: Do not remove the steering gear for this procedure.

svcprocinfo.para: Before a seal can be replaced, you must identify the manufacturing date of the steering gear. This can be done by following the steering gear IDENTIFICATIONprocedure.

warning.para: Failure to replace all seals, cotter pins, retainers and critical fasteners may result in an accident, injury or death.

step1.para: Park the vehicle on a clean, dry, solid surface, preferably concrete. Set the parking brake and block the wheels. Place the transmission in neutral. Make sure the engine is off.
Tilt the hood or cab.
Loosen and remove the pinch bolt on the lower end yoke of the steering shaft.
Remove the lower yoke from the steering gear input shaft. If necessary, secure the steering shaft so it will not be in the way.

important.para: Do not pull the slip shaft out of the steering shaft. This would require re-phasing at time of installation.

step1.para: Place the drain pan under the power steering gear. Draining the system is not necessary, but some fluid will be lost.
Use a ratchet and 15 or 16 mm socket to loosen and remove the 4 bearing cap cover bolts and cover ( Figure 17).

figure.caption: Figure 17. Loosen and Remove Bearing Cap Cover Bolts

caution.para: Do not turn the input shaft during repairs. Turning the shaft or mixing components will cause damage to the bearing cap and actuating shaft assembly.

important.para: The thrust washer may stick to the bearing cap cover. If this happens, re-install the thrust washer in the steering gear ( Figure 18 and Figure 19).

figure.caption: Figure 18. Re-Install Thrust Washer In Steering Gear
Figure 19. Re-Install Thrust Washer In Steering Gear

step1.para: Pry the salt seal out of the bearing cap cover with a screwdriver (Figure 20).

figure.caption: Figure 20. Pry Salt Seal Out Of Bearing Cap

step1.para: Lightly tap a 1 inch socket and short extension to remove the input shaft seal and backup washer. Discard the seals and backup washer ( Figure 21).

figure.caption: Figure 21. Remove Input Shaft Seal And Backup Washer

warning.para: Wear safety glasses and use light hammer blows to prevent damage to the extension.

step1.para: Remove the bearing cap cover O-ring and discard.
Clean the bearing cap cover with an approved solvent and blow dry with low pressure air.

warning.para: Always wear safety glasses and use low pressure air only to clean parts.

step1.para: If working on a service bearing cap cover, use a punch or screwdriver to drive the seal out ( Figure 22).

figure.caption: Figure 22. Drive Seal Out Of Service Bearing Cap

step1.para: Place the cover on a work bench with it lying on the outer surface ( Figure 23).

figure.caption: Figure 23. Lay Cover On Outer Surface

note.para: There are two different diameter seal bores. Use the gage provided in the seal kit to determine the seal to use. If the gage fits with the side stamped "Gage A" facing up, use the color-coded seal. If it does not fit, use the non-color-coded seal ( Figure 24).

step1.para: Use an arbor press and the gage (side stamped driver) to install the seal ( Figure 25).
Install a new cover O-ring and cover the shaft with white grease or a similar product (Figure 26).
Press the salt seal into the bearing cap cover until it is flush with the cover ( Figure 27).

note.para: Make sure the seal lip faces outward.

step1.para: Re-install the bearing cap cover on the bearing cap ( Figure 28).

caution.para: Do not damage the input shaft seal during installation.

step1.para: Install the 4 bearing cap cover bolts and tighten to 53 to 63 ft-lbs. (72 to 85 Nm) ( Figure 29).

figure.caption: Figure 29. Install 4 Bearing Cap Cover Bolts

step1.para: Install rubber boot on input shaft ( Figure 30).

If you are working on the service style bearing cap cover, measure the diameter of the actuating shaft. Select either the white, red or orange-colored salt seal. Slide the salt seal over the shaft, insuring the lip of the seal is facing out. With your fingers, push the seal into the cover until it is flush with the top of the cap ( Figure 31).
Slip the lower end yoke of the steering shaft onto the input shaft so the pinch bolt hole lines up with the whistle notch in the input shaft.
Re-install the pinch bolt and nut and tighten. Refer to GROUP 05 - STEERING in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for the proper torque value for the vehicle and type of column being serviced.
Use the hand grease gun to pump a small amount of grease into the grease fitting until grease can be seen coming out around the salt seal.
Check the fluid level in the power steering reservoir and make sure that it is full.
Start the vehicle and allow it to idle. Check for leaks.
Shut the unit off after checking for leaks and check fluid level.
Clean any fluid from the power steering gear and remove the drain pan.
Lower the cab or hood.
